metadata./Keywords: Premature ventricular complex; Pregnancy; Eptomarginal trabecula; Radiofrequency ablation; Arrhythmias
metadata./Title: Ventricular premature beats in a pregnant woman originating from trabeculae carneae in the right ventricle treated with radiofrequency ablation without X-ray guidance: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background Premature ventricular beats increase the cardiac load in pregnant women, leading to symptoms, such 
as palpitations. In severe instances, they may reduce placental perfusion, potentially causing intrauterine distress 
and developmental delays in the fetus, which could result in miscarriage or stillbirth. Fluoroscopy-less ablation offers 
significant advantages for pregnant women, including reduced radiation exposure, enhanced treatment precision, 
and a lower incidence of postprocedure complications.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case Presentation This case describes how radiofrequency catheter ablation was used on a pregnant Chinese 
woman who was identified with frequent ventricular premature beats originating from the high septal margin trabeculae carneae of the right ventricle. The rarity of this premature beat focus poses challenges for electrophysiology 
mapping and ablation; however, the ablation ultimately succeeded. In this case report, the clinical manifestations, 
electrocardiogram, ablation procedure, and patient prognosis are reported and discussed.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion X-ray free ablation clearly reduces radiation exposure while maintaining a high success rate and safety 
of the ablation procedure.
Keywords  Premature ventricular complex, Pregnancy, Eptomarginal trabecula, Radiofrequency ablation, Arrhythmias
Background
Radiofrequency catheter ablation (RFCA) is an effective 
treatment for ventricular arrhythmias, but traditional 
procedures rely on X-ray fluoroscopy, which carries radi ation risks. RFCA without X-ray guidance technology 
uses an advanced three-dimensional calibration system, reduces radiation exposure, and has unique applica tion value, especially in pregnant patients [1]. Pregnant 
women are more sensitive to X-ray radiation because of 
their special physiological state, and premature ventricu lar beats may affect the health of mothers and children, 
requiring timely and effective treatment [2]. Ventricular 
premature beats originating from right ventricular tra beculae are more difficult to ablate because of the com plexity of the anatomical structure [3]. The application 
of X-ray-free guidance provides a new treatment option. 
This case report shares the experience of RFCA with out X-ray guidance in treating pregnant women with 
premature ventricular beats originating from the right Open Access

ventricular trabeculae carneae, with the aim of providing 
a reference for clinicians and advancing the development 
of this technique. With the advancement of technology, 
X-ray-free guided RFCA is expected to become a safer 
and more effective treatment in the future.
Case presentation
A 29-year-old Chinese woman was hospitalized with 
a history of intermittent palpitations for 1 year and one 
episode of syncope. At 1 year prior, she experienced pal pitations, chest pain, dizziness, headache, and amaurosis 
without apparent cause, and no diagnosis or treatment 
was provided. Then, 1 month prior, the patient experi enced an episode of dizziness, syncope, and incontinence 
without any obvious reason. The 24-hour Holter Moni tor at the local hospital revealed a total of 49,420 prema ture ventricular beats (PVBs), accounting for 32% of the 
total heart beats. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) 
revealed an enlarged left atrium (anteroposterior diam eter of 40 mm) and left ventricle (end-diastolic diameter 
of 55 mm), and a normal ejection fraction (65%). Upon 
admission, the patient exhibited overall fair health and 
was in the 21st week of gestation. The other medical his tory, including personal history, family history, allergic 
history, and trauma history, was normal. The examina tion at admission revealed an enlargement of the heart 
boundaries toward the lower left, an irregular cardiac 
rhythm, and the absence of any murmur. Frequent PVBs 
not only significantly affected the patient’s quality of life but also potentially represented a risk to the future 
delivery. Since onset, the patient had neither taken nor 
expressed willingness to take any medication to sup press ectopic beats. Thus, RFCA was recommended. A 
multidisciplinary team including obstetricians also rec ommended RFCA, and obstetricians participated in the 
whole process of ablation. The patient and her family 
signed informed consent for RFCA.
The surface electrocardiogram (ECG) indicated that 
the QRS waveforms were positive in leads II and aVF, 
negative in lead III, and QS pattern in  V1-2. In addition, 
the R wave transition of the chest leads was between 
leads  V4 and  V5. All of these ECG features supported the 
deduction that the PVBs are likely to originate from the 
tricuspid annulus (Fig.  1). During the procedure, lido caine was administered as a local anesthetic, after which 
a guidewire was inserted under the guidance of ultra sound through the femoral vein to the superior vena 
cava (SVC), after which a right 0 long sheath was deliv ered into the right atrium. Under the guidance of the 
Carto system, the tricuspid annulus was first mapped, 
and the earliest local electrogram was noted around the 
tricuspid annulus, which was only 15 ms earlier than the 
initial point of the QRS waveforms in the body surface 
ECG. The catheter was subsequently inserted further into 
the high septal region, and the local electrogram at the 
site of trabeculae carneae was found to be 33 ms earlier 
than the body surface QRS, with a unipolar signal of QS 
type. Radiofrequency was delivered at a power of 35 W, 
Fig. 1 Preoperative surface electrocardiogram
Page 3 of 4
 Li et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:587 
 
and a temperature limit of 43 °C. Then, 5 seconds after 
radiofrequency delivery, the PVCs disappeared, and the 
ablation was continued for 240 seconds (Fig.  2). No PVCs 
were detected during the 30-minute observation period. 
No premature ventricular beats were detected via body 
surface electrocardiogram after 12 months of follow-up.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Studies have demonstrated that frequent PVBs can con tribute to the development of cardiomyopathy and heart 
failure, as well as the progression of preexisting cardio myopathy. However, these conditions are often revers ible with timely treatment [4]. Additionally, PVBs can 
increase the burden on a pregnant woman’s heart or even 
lead to heart failure [5]. The young woman in this case 
had a history of syncope. TTE revealed left ventricular 
enlargement, indicating the early stage of dilated car diomyopathy. However, the specific pathophysiological 
process behind the development of left ventricular dys function caused by PVBs remains unclear. This may be 
secondary to the asynchronous contraction of ventricles 
and ventricular remodeling produced by PVBs.
In this case, the operator prioritized minimizing or 
completely avoiding intraoperative radiation expo sure. Ultrasound guidance was employed to advance 
the guidewire into the superior vena cava, enabling 
secure placement of the catheter into the right atrium. 
Simultaneously, the Carto system facilitated accurate reconstruction of the cardiac chambers, with particu lar emphasis on the regions of interest. A fetal radia tion dose under 50 mGy is considered safe and does 
not result in adverse effects [6 ]. The procedure was 
conducted without X-ray exposure, demonstrating the 
feasibility of catheter ablation for PVBs in pregnant 
women without fluoroscopy. This method adheres to 
the strict safety standards for both the mother and the 
fetus, highlighting the feasibility of non-fluoroscopic 
catheter ablation in pregnant patients.
As mentioned above, the patient’s preoperative sur face electrocardiogram initially suggested that the PVB 
site was likely located around the tricuspid annulus, but 
no ideal ablation target was found around it. The cath eter continued to extend to the ventricular site and was 
found to be a suitable and effective target at the sep tum edge of the trabeculae carneae, indicating that the 
body surface electrocardiogram could be used only as 
a rough guiding tool rather than a definitely error-free 
approach to determine the originating focus and abla tion target of the PVBs. Owing to the high anatomical 
variability of the intracavitary structure of the right 
ventricle (similar to the intracavitary structure of the 
left ventricle), precise PVB localization via surface elec trocardiograms is often difficult, especially because the 
incidence here is relatively rare [7 ]. Finally, accurate 
intraoperative mapping was required to identify the 
exact ablation target.
Fig. 2. Three-dimensional electroanatomic mapping. The ablation target was located in the region of septal papillary muscle of the right ventricle, 
with local electrogram being 33 ms earlier than the QRS of the body surface ECG and QS pattern of the unipolar electrogram. Ablation at this site 
successfully eliminated the PVBs
Page 4 of 4 Li et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:587 
Limitations remain in this case. Owing to the high cost, 
the patient refused to undergo intracardiac echocardiog raphy (ICE). It is a powerful imaging modality for guid ing electrophysiology and structural heart interventions. 
Real-time ICE imaging has an expanding role in provid ing uninterrupted guidance for catheter-based ablation 
for cardiac arrhythmia [8]. However, in this case, abla tion was successfully completed at the trabeculae carneae 
mapped by Carto without the use of ICE.
For further reference, the use of ICE can significantly 
lower risks, shorten procedure time, reduce compli cations, and increase success rates for patients with 
arrhythmia requiring ablation. ICE has increased in 
importance in cardiac interventions in recent years 
because of its significant advantages in improving proce dural safety, reducing patient discomfort, lowering costs, 
and minimizing radiation exposure [9].
This case report differs from previous literature primarily 
in its focus on the specific population of pregnant women, 
employing a multidisciplinary approach involving obstetrics 
and other departments to minimize fetal impact, an aspect 
not heavily emphasized in previous studies. Additionally, the 
right ventricular septal trabecular anatomy is complex, yet 
the patient underwent successful ablation surgery without 
the use of ICE owing to financial constraints, which is rare. 
However, we strongly advocate for the use of ICE, as it is 
beneficial for the success of the procedure and the reduction 
of postoperative complications [10]. We believe that ICE is 
effective in surgery because of its greater safety and efficacy, 
enabling real-time dynamic observation of cardiac struc tures, especially in complex anatomical areas. Furthermore, 
ICE can improve surgical success rates and reduce compli cations by displaying subtle cardiac anatomical landmarks. 
Finally, ICE can shorten the surgical time, reduce radiation 
exposure, and be more beneficial for special populations, 
such as pregnant women.
Conclusion
This case report describes the successful application of 
X-ray-free guided RFCA for the treatment of premature 
ventricular beats of the right ventricular trabecular carneae 
in a pregnant woman. The technique demonstrated the 
clear advantage of reducing radiation exposure while main taining a high success rate and safety. The patient recovered 
well from the procedure without complications, confirming 
the clinical value of this approach in specific clinical situa tions. This successful experience supports the prioritization 
of X-ray-free guided radiofrequency ablation as a viable 
option for the treatment of ventricular arrhythmias in preg nant women or other radiation-sensitive patient populations. 
Future studies should focus on evaluating the long-term effi cacy and generalizability of this technique to further opti mize arrhythmia treatment strategies.Author contributions
XYL and MAUH conceived and designed the analysis; TL collected the data; 
TL and LZ contributed data and wrote the paper; ZY revised and guided 
the paper. All authors have read and agreed to the published version of the 
manuscript.
Funding
No funding was required for this work.
Data availability
All the data is available in the manuscript and any further information can 
be obtained from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
Declarations
Ethics approval and consent to participate:
Ethics committee of general hospital of Ningxia medical university 
approved the study for publication. Informed consent was obtained from 
the subject involved in the study.
Consent for publication
Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication 
of this case report and any accompanying images. A copy of the written 
consent is available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal.
Competing interests
The authors declare that they have no competing interests.
